awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Physically-Based Simulation of Strand-Liquid Interaction
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops algorithms that predict the dynamics of liquids interacting with thin flexible strands.  The interaction of strands with each other, and with liquids, is a fundamental physical consideration in myriad contexts.  Therefore, the development of computer algorithms that can predict the physics of liquid-strand interaction has the potential to spur advances in many important scientific and engineering fields of investigation.  New algorithms are needed to improve realism in virtual reality, one of the grand challenges in engineering as recognized by the National Academy of Engineering, and also to advance important problems in biology, transoceanic communications, robotics, graphical animation, and industrial product design.  A fundamental challenge addressed by this project is accounting for the many ways in which liquids and strands interact.  These interactions involve numerous physical ingredients at distinct spatiotemporal scales.  Efficient integration of these components in numerical algorithms remains an important and challenging problem.  Solving this problem will involve development of algorithms that model complex, multi-scale, multi-physics systems.  The process of designing such algorithms will itself produce new insights transferrable across scientific, engineering, and creative disciplines.  Students trained by this project will become highly skilled in developing, extending, and harnessing numerical and graphical algorithms for applications spanning the natural sciences and engineering.  The investigators will encourage participation from underrepresented groups at the doctoral, masters, and undergraduate levels.

The research studies numerical modeling of liquid-strand interactions involving the consideration of multiple physical ingredients, including strand elasticity, liquid inertia, capillary action, wetting-induced tribological changes, inter-strand contact and friction, as external forces like gravity, and dimensionless groups, at multiple spatiotemporal scales, and over transient periods.  Unlike existing methods that model certain specific processes in isolation, this project emphasizes broad-purpose simulation of liquid-strand interaction.  This focus requires thoughtful selection of a computer model for each physical ingredient, as well as special attention to compatibility between choices, so that reconciliation of all the ingredients in different combinations becomes tractable.  In particular, this project will be carried out with two major thrusts, namely, the numerical modeling of strands interacting with Newtonian and Non-Newtonian fluids.  These thrusts will also crosscut research on robust simulation of hair contacts and performance acceleration for interactive simulation.

por.por_cntn:
Long, thin, strands of material are prevalent in everyday life; examples include a strand of hair, a surgical suture, flagella on a microorganism, or undersea internet cables. The interaction of thin strands with each other, and with liquids, is a fundamental physical consideration in a myriad contexts, including computer graphics (depicting hair and fur, modeling painterly brushes), virtual reality (surgical training environments), consumer products (cosmetics, cleaning), industrial manufacturing (continuous spinning of rayon, uses of steel wool), ﬁshing (nets, lines), food science (soluble ﬁber, fettuccine), textiles (knits, weaves), civil engineering (undersea internet cables, car washes, street cleaners), biology (ﬂagellar locomotion, DNA, underwater spiders, pond-skating insects), natural environments (seaweed, oil spills and animal fur), and robotics (biomimetic designs, surgical robots).

The research objective of this project was to develop algorithms that predict the dynamics of liquids interacting with thin strands and other thin materials. If we can create computer algorithms that predict the physics of liquid-strand interaction, then we are one step closer to addressing important problems in ﬁelds such as virtual reality, biology, transoceanic communications, robotics, graphical animation, and industrial product design.

The research goal required consideration of multiple physical processes, spatial and temporal scales, numerical computing and algorithmic efﬁciency. The interaction of strands with liquids is varied, from submersion of a cable into the ocean, to wetting of hair, to dripping of a paintbrush. The goal of this project was to investigate a computational method that accounts for the varied physical processes, and that applies to a broad range of problems spanning multiple engineering, scientiﬁc and creative disciplines.

The project resulted in several research outcomes addressing these goals. The researchers developed efficient computer modeling algorithms for predicting the physics of liquid-strand interaction involving a mix of physical ingredients, including elasticity of the strand (bending, twisting, stretching forces), surface tension of the liquid (capillarity forces), inertia, gravity, and frictional contact forces between strands. These varied “ingredients” allow for a broad range of problems to be modeled by combining ingredients. For example, the imbibition and uptake of watercolor by a paintbrush is dominated by competition between capillarity and gravity.

 

In the first thrust, the project developed algorithms for the interaction of strands with Newtonian ﬂuids, the most commonly known one being water. The researchers developed a novel multi-component simulation framework that treats many of the key physical mechanisms governing the dynamics of wet hair. The foundations of our approach are a discrete rod model for hair and a particle-in-cell model for fluids. To treat the thin layer of liquid that clings to the hair, the new method augments each hair strand with a concise representation of a surrounding liquid film. The researchers developed an efficient approach to solve the motion of the liquid film along the length of each hair, accounting also for surface tension-induced cohesion effects between adjacent hairs, and for drag between hair and the surrounding body of liquid. 

 

In the second thrust, the project developed algorithms for modeling the interaction of liquids with complex assemblies of strands, for instance, many strands woven together into a fabric. The researchers developed a model that predicts the dynamics of partially and fully saturated woven and knit fabrics interacting with liquid, including the effects of buoyancy, nonlinear drag, pore (capillary) pressure, dripping, and convection-diffusion. Their new model evolves the velocity fields of both the liquid and solid relying on mixture theory, as well as tracking a scalar saturation variable that affects the pore pressure forces in the fluid. The results significantly extend previous numerical cloth and fluid models to support the diverse behaviors of wet fabric, as demonstrated by results in challenging problem scenarios involving splashing, wringing, and collisions with obstacles.

 

In the third thrust, the researchers went beyond Newtonian liquids to consider the broader class of compressible, shear-dependent liquids, such as oil paint, mud, cream, melted chocolate, and pasta sauce. The researchers generalized and extended the work of the earlier thrusts, to encompass challenging scenarios, involving splashing, shaking, and agitating the liquid which causes the strands to stick together and become entangled.
